Literature Review: Myostatin, a skeletal muscle chalone, has been a subject of extensive research in the field of muscle physiology and growth regulation. Discovered 25 years ago, myostatin (GDF-8) was initially identified as a new member of the transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) family, which plays a crucial role in regulating various cellular processes, including growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. As a master regulator of skeletal muscle mass, myostatin is produced by skeletal myofibers, circulates in the blood, and acts back on myofibers to limit growth (1). This chalone-like mechanism of action suggests that myostatin functions as a negative feedback regulator of muscle mass, controlling tissue size and preventing excessive muscle growth (2). The elucidation of the molecular, cellular, and physiological mechanisms underlying myostatin activity has provided valuable insights into the regulation of muscle growth and development (3). Furthermore, research has shown that myostatin is involved in the regulation of muscle fiber type, with studies demonstrating that myostatin inhibits the expression of fast-twitch muscle fibers (4). In addition, myostatin has been shown to regulate the expression of genes involved in muscle growth and differentiation, including the myogenic regulatory factors (MRFs) (5). The role of myostatin in regulating muscle growth and development has also been implicated in various physiological and pathological conditions, including muscle atrophy, cancer, and metabolic disorders (6-8). The discovery of myostatin has also led to the identification of other chalone-like molecules, including activin and latency-associated peptide (LAP), which share similar mechanisms of action with myostatin (9). These findings suggest that the chalone mechanism of action may be more widespread than previously thought, operating in various tissues beyond skeletal muscle. However, the specific mechanisms and regulatory pathways underlying myostatin activity in different tissues remain poorly understood. Recent studies have begun to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying myostatin signaling, including the involvement of the TGF-β receptor type I (TβRI) and the Smad signaling pathway (10). These findings have significant implications for our understanding of muscle growth and development, as well as the regulation of tissue size in various physiological and pathological contexts. In conclusion, myostatin is a critical regulator of skeletal muscle mass, and its chalone-like mechanism of action has significant implications for our understanding of muscle growth and development. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the mechanisms underlying myostatin activity in different tissues and to explore the therapeutic potential of myostatin inhibitors in various diseases.
